body.p: A Kentucky attorney and politician. Educated at preparatory schools. Studied law and admitted to the bar in 1809. Practiced law in Bardtown, Kentucky. Married to Margaret Crepps Wickliffe. Father of Elizabeth B Wickliffe Kinkead, Mary Wickliffe Merrick, Robert Charles Wickliffe, Margaret Wickliffe Holt, Nancy Christian Wickliffe Yulee, and Julia Wickliffe Beckham. Served in the War of 1812 as an aide to General Joseph Winlock and later as an aide to General Samuel Caldwell. Elected as a member of the Kentucky House of Representatives from 1812 to 1813. Elected as a member of the Kentucky House of Representatives in 1822, 1823, and from 1833 to 1835. Served as Speaker of the Kentucky House of Representatives in 1834. Served the Fifth Congressional District of Kentucky as a Jackson Republican member of the United States House of Representative from 1823 to 1824 and as a Jacksonian from 1825 to 1832. Served the Fifth Congressional District of Kentucky as a Unionist member of the United States House of Representative from 1861 to 1863. Served as lieutenant governor of the Commonwealth of Kentucky from 1836 to 1839. Upon the death of Governor James Clark, served as governor of the Commonwealth of Kentucky from 1839 to 1840. Served as United States Postmaster General from 1841 to 1845. Served as a special agent to the Republic of Texas under U.S. President James K. Polk in 1845. Served as a member of the 1849 Kentucky Constitutional Convention. Served as a member of the peace conference held in Washington, D.C. in 1861. Unsuccessfully campaigned as a Kentucky Peace Democrats for governor in 1863 against Thomas E. Bramlette. Served as a delegate to the 1864 Democratic National Convention.
